verses.verse: (Job Curses the Day He Was Born) After this Job opened his mouth and cursed the day of his birth.
Job said:
(Job 10.18; Jer 20.14) “Let the day perish in which I was born, and the night that said, ‘A male is conceived.’
Let that day be darkness! May God above not seek it or light shine on it.
(Job 10.21; Ps 23.4; Jer 2.6) Let gloom and deep darkness claim it. Let clouds settle upon it; let the blackness of the day terrify it.
(Job 23.17) That night—let thick darkness seize it! let it not rejoice among the days of the year; let it not come into the number of the months.
Yes, let that night be barren; let no joyful cry be heard (Heb come) in it.
(Job 41.10) Let those curse it who curse the Sea, (Cn: Heb day) those who are skilled to rouse up Leviathan.
(Job 41.18) Let the stars of its dawn be dark; let it hope for light but have none; may it not see the eyelids of the morning—
because it did not shut the doors of my mother’s womb and hide trouble from my eyes.
(Job 10.18) “Why did I not die at birth, come forth from the womb and expire?
(Gen 30.3; Isa 66.12) Why were there knees to receive me or breasts for me to suck?
Now I would be lying down and quiet; I would be asleep; then I would be at rest
(Job 12.17, 18; 15.28) with kings and counselors of the earth who rebuild ruins for themselves,
or with princes who have gold, who fill their houses with silver.
(Eccl 6.3) Or why was I not buried like a stillborn child, like an infant that never sees the light?
(Job 17.16) There the wicked cease from troubling, and there the weary are at rest.
There the prisoners are at ease together; they do not hear the voice of the taskmaster.
The small and the great are there, and the slaves are free from their masters.
(1 Sam 1.10; Prov 31.6; Isa 38.15; Ezek 27.31) “Why is light given to one in misery and life to the bitter in soul,
(Rev 9.6) who long for death, but it does not come, and dig for it more than for hidden treasures;
who rejoice exceedingly and are glad when they find the grave?
(Job 19.6, 8, 12; Lam 3.7) Why is light given to one who cannot see the way, whom God has fenced in?
(Ps 42.3, 4) For my sighing comes like (Heb before) my bread, and my groanings are poured out like water.
Truly the thing that I fear comes upon me, and what I dread befalls me.
I am not at ease, nor am I quiet; I have no rest, but trouble comes.”
